body.p: Whereas Thomas Wadlington has been sentenced to be han^g^d on the 1st day of March for the killing of a certain Cartwright about 12 months since. Now therefore we the people of Charleston and its vicinity, beleveing that the criminal should be entirely pardoned recommend him to the mercy of your own eccellency, as to the morality and good form of said Wadlington, none stands higher, this is the only dificulty we have ever heard of his geting in, during a considerable age.

Sir ^your^ Honor may not conclude that because this sheat is not filled with petitioners that we could get no more but we conclude we have enough. When a thousand or too men have been raised there voises to you in behalf of inocenc it seems useless to annoy you with ^more^ and if you will turn a deaf year and a colt heart to your petitioners and Wadlington should be hung, his bood will be sprinkled on the mouths of the doors of Princeton Court house, The base within will be in stain with a christions Blood and all the will wear the aspect of mornful drapery. whilst the verry pillers of the might building
utter groans of Lamentations for the cruelty of the execution.. Sir in a previous letter that I directed to your honor, I did not have the evidence of the case before me, but have adverted to it in remarks, beleaving I had been correctly informed. The great wonder is that your many petitiones had not prayed for young Wadlington to be released from penatitiary who was in the same charge of Thomas W his father,

O cruel fate if he should die
on a degarded cross,
for doing what all men would do
That was not made of dross
for God has planted in the heart
Of every man of sense
A will to take anothers life
When in his own defefense
Especially when weapons were
In his assailants hand
should he forsake his premises
And leave his house and land
And leave his home and hide ^his^ face
In some secluded place
and leave yeald claims manliness
and bear the worlds disgrace
Whilst life shall last, false well but
He will defend himself, It is a wright due
to him his children and his wife
I requested you to send my letter back to Madisonville to G Ligon please send this, Sir will not trubble you more, But will allways admire and love you
